documents.headline: COVID-19: protect great apes during human pandemics
documents.source: Nature Publishing Group | Earth and Environment channel
documents.summary: Emory University, Atlanta, Georgia, USA. On behalf of the Great Ape Health Consortium (see Supplementary Information) Robert Koch Institute, Berlin, Germany. On behalf of the Great Ape Health Consortium (see Supplementary Information) SARS-CoV-2, the coronavirus responsible for the current COVID-19 pandemic, is also a threat to our closest living relatives, the great apes.

documents.headline: Insights from nanomedicine into chloroquine efficacy against COVID-19
documents.summary: Chloroquine — an approved malaria drug — is known in nanomedicine research for the investigation of nanoparticle uptake in cells, and may have potential for the treatment of COVID-19. Subscribe to Journal. Get full journal access for 1 year. All prices are NET prices. VAT will be added later in the checkout.

documents.headline: Scientists exposed to coronavirus wonder: why weren’t we notified?
documents.summary: Health departments around the world are struggling to test for coronavirus and notify people who might have been exposed to the disease.Credit: Jeff Pachoud/AFP via Getty “I’ve been in the ICU fighting … wait for it … Coronavirus!” tweeted a 38-year-old geneticist on Sunday. Clement Chow, from the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, was in a hospital intensive care unit (ICU) in Utah.

documents.headline: Coronavirus: three things all governments and their science advisers must do now
documents.summary: “Some of the most important choices about a nation’s physical health are made, or not made, by a handful of men, in secret.” Sixty-odd years ago, the chemist, writer and civil servant Charles Percy Snow revealed in his book Science and Government the shocking extent to which science advice to governments during the Second World War had lacked evidence.

documents.headline: Network-based drug repurposing for novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV/SARS-CoV-2
documents.summary: Human coronaviruses (HCoVs), including severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV, also known as SARS-CoV-2), lead global epidemics with high morbidity and mortality. However, there are currently no effective drugs targeting 2019-nCoV/SARS-CoV-2. Drug repurposing, representing as an effective drug discovery strategy from existing drugs, could shorten the time and reduce the cost compared to de novo drug discovery.

documents.headline: Don’t rush to deploy COVID-19 vaccines and drugs without sufficient safety guarantees
documents.summary: We must urgently develop measures to tackle the new coronavirus — but safety always comes first, says Shibo Jiang. Shibo Jiang is a professor of virology at the School of Basic Medical Sciences, Fudan University, Shanghai, China, and at the New York Blood Center, New York, USA. Around the world, I am seeing efforts to support ‘quick-fix’ programmes aimed at developing vaccines and therapeutics against COVID-19.

documents.headline: Exposed: cells’ sugary secrets
documents.summary: A 3D structure of a glycoprotein spike that helps coronaviruses attach to cells. The spike is decorated with glycans that stop antibodies binding.Credit: X. Xiong et al./J. Virol. Just 22 amino acids are all that’s needed to make all the world’s proteins. Four nucleotide bases encode biology’s blueprints in DNA.

documents.headline: How China is planning to go to Mars amid the coronavirus outbreak
documents.source: Nature Publishing Group | Earth and Environment channel
documents.summary: The launch is on track for July, as Europe and Russia announce a two-year delay in their journey to the red planet. China's Long March 5 rocket will carry its Mars probe into space.Credit: AFP/Getty China’s first journey to Mars is one of the most anticipated space missions of the year. But with parts of the country in some form of lockdown because of the coronavirus, the mission teams have had to find creative ways to continue their work.

documents.headline: Coronavirus and children, deep-sea microbes and a bold new climate law
documents.source: Nature Publishing Group | Earth and Environment channel
documents.summary: A fire engine surrounded by bush-fire smoke in February near the town of Bumbalong, south of Canberra, Australia.Credit: Peter Parks/AFP/Getty Climate change contributed to Australia’s extreme bush-fire weather. Global warming increased by at least 30% the risk of the weather conditions that drove the recent catastrophic bush fires in Australia, says a group of climate scientists who analysed the disaster.
